subject: Adds DataNode decommissioning support to HDP Plugin
commit_message:
Adds DataNode decommissioning support to HDP Plugin

This patch adds support for decommissioning HDFS datanodes
  during a de-scaling operation in Sahara.  The HDP
  plugin will now make requests to the Ambari server
  in the cluster to decommision any DataNodes deployed
  on the instances that are being shutdown.  This
  change is required to allow HDFS to gracefully
  handle the case where a set of DataNodes are
  being shutdown due to a scaling change.
This patch adds this support for HDP 2.0.6 only.
A new method has been added to the AmbariClient class
  for HDP 2.0.6 to implement the set of REST API
  calls to Ambari Server to start and monitor the
  process of decommissioning HDFS DataNodes on
  the machines that will be de-scaled.
The AmbariPlugin's implementation of decommission_nodes()
  has been modified to use the HDP 2.0.6 AmbariClient to
  handle the decommissioning (in the case of 2.0.6).
  The plugin will throw an exception if this call is
  attempted for an HDP 1.3.2 cluster.

Closes-Bug: #1335923

subject: Fix SLO test with old simplejson
commit_message:
Fix SLO test with old simplejson

Our requirements.txt contains "simplejson>=2.0.9". With that version,
attempting to decode invalid JSON raises ValueError, not
simplejson.JSONDecodeError. In fact, there is no such thing as
JSONDecodeError; it isn't introduced until a later version. Also,
stdlib's json module doesn't have a JSONDecodeError either. However,
JSONDecodeError inherits from ValueError, so we can just catch that
instead.

Also added a better failure message when invalid JSON is detected;
we'll now fail immediately instead of later in some assertEqual().

subject: Do not allow resize to zero disk flavor
commit_message:
Do not allow resize to zero disk flavor

For some reason nova allows creating a flavor with a disk_size of 0,
when an instance is booted using such flavor its disk will use the
native base image size as the size of the ephemeral root volume (from
the ops docs:
http://docs.openstack.org/openstack-ops/content/flavors.html).

Even though having the disk_size=0 means that the instance's disk can
have any imaginable size, nova will still allow to resize that instance
to any flavor defining disk_size >= 0 but it won't shrink the disk if it
is bigger than the new disk_size.

This patch add check to prevent resize to zero disk flavor except
when both current and new disk are 0.

DocImpact

subject: Don't reset MySQL database from image
commit_message:
Don't reset MySQL database from image

Currently we initialize a database during the image build and
store it in the image. We then use this database as an initial
database for MySQL. This causes problems as you have to reset
the database to match the end MySQL configuration and if this
goes wrong you can corrupt your database.

This patch removes all that. By not carrying the initial database
from the build we don't have to reset it, and we can let MySQL
create it with the correct configuration.

Delete operation does not have limit for nodes, but it

using network. Cobbler installed at master node provide
ability to boot using network and have limited resources.

To prevent high load for Cobbler this changes add two things:
* split all nodes to groups (default - 10) which process
in series;
* wait some time (default - 10 sec) between such groups.

Both of this parameters can be changed in config.

subject: Missing node driver interface validation API
commit_message:
Missing node driver interface validation API

This patch implements missing API test for node validation.

There are three categories of driver interfaces:

- `Core` interfaces provide the essential functionality for Ironic
   within OpenStack, and may be depended upon by other services.
   All drivers must implement these interfaces. Presently, the Core
   interfaces are "power" and "deploy".
- `Standard` interfaces provide functionality beyond the needs of
  OpenStack, but which has been standardized across all drivers and
  becomes part of Ironic's API.
  If a driver implements this interface, it must adhere to the standard.
  This is presented to encourage vendors to work together with the
  Ironic project and implement common features in a consistent way,
  thus reducing the burden on consumers of the API.
  Presently, the Standard interfaces are rescue and console.
- The `Vendor` interface allows an exemption to the API contract when
  a vendor wishes to expose unique functionality provided by their
  hardware and is unable to do so within the core or standard interfaces.
  In this case, Ironic will merely relay the message from the API service
  to the appropriate driver.

As all drivers must implement core interfaces, I am checking only
core interfaces for response body validation.

part of blueprint: missing-baremetal-api-test

subject: Fix broken formatting of processutils.execute log statement
commit_message:
Fix broken formatting of processutils.execute log statement

The processutils.execute function will log a message about
each command it runs which looks like this:

   Running cmd (subprocess): /bin/echo hello world

In the following commit:

  commit cdcc19c1d78a4a88daabfb64b27abd4924aa442d
  Author: Brad Pokorny <bpokorny@us.ibm.com>
  Date:   Sun May 18 18:26:33 2014 +0000

    Mask passwords that are included in commands

The command is passthrough through logging.mask_password
first. Unfortunately this method expects a string as its
parameter, but is given a list of strings instead. This
causes it to stringify the list object. The result is that
the log message ends up being mangled to look like this:

   Running cmd (subprocess): [ ' / b i n / e c h o ' ,
   ' h e l l o   w o r l d ' ]

The execute method should have been masking the password
after turning the list of strings into a single string,
instead of before.

subject: OSprofiler notifier based on oslo.messaging notify API
commit_message:
OSprofiler notifier based on oslo.messaging notify API

On every profiler.start() and profiler.stop() OSprofiler calls notify() method.
By default it does nothing (it was done to simplify integration, and make
osprofiler fully independent from rest of OS).

Service that would like to use OSprofiler and send real notifications to real
collector, should change default notify() func. To do that it should call:
osprofiler.notifier.set_notifier(real_notfier_func).

The goal of integration is to make it really simple (without hot patching) to
use profiler in production and be able to retrieve results via OpenStack API.
As well we need centralized collector for all these profiler notifications.

Fortunately there is oslo.messaging & Ceilometer that can cover fully this
task. So we decided to use as real_notifier_func Ceilometer and oslo.messaging
with  notify API. In our case notify() should call
oslo.messaging.notify.Notifier().info method with "profiler.<service_name>"
event type and profiler payload information as a message.

To avoid copy paste in all projects, we decide to put in oslo.messaging code
that that properly sets up osprofiler notifier, with properly created notify
instance.

subject: Avoid deleting transient cluster before job is started
commit_message:
Avoid deleting transient cluster before job is started

In order to run job on a transient cluster client needs to execute
two commands:
 * create cluster with is_transient=true
 * run job on it in a regular manner

We terminate unneeded transient clusters in a periodic job, which
terminates cluster if cluster is transient and no job is running on it
at a time. We also do not terminate cluster if its lifetime is smaller
then config parameter min_transient_cluster_active_time. For some
reason the parameter is set to 0 by default, which could cause
premature cluster termination if periodic task runs between
cluster creation and job execution.

Also added unit tests to verify min_transient_cluster_active_time.

subject: vmware: Refactor: fold volume_util.py into volumeops.py
commit_message:
vmware: Refactor: fold volume_util.py into volumeops.py

volume_util.py seems to have originally been intended to be a general
repository of operations on volumes. In fact, it was an arbitrary
collection of iscsi functions which were exclusively called by
VMwareVolumeOps with VMwareVolumeOps private data as arguments.

This change moves all functions from volume_util.py into
VMwareVolumeOps in volumeops.py. This makes it simpler to read and
understand the code, as there is now only a single place to look for
iscsi functions. It also moves StorageError into volumeops.py, as that
is the only place it is used. Arguments have been updated to use
private data directly rather than having them passed in. In addition,
function names have been updated to accurately reflect their actual
purpose.

There are no functional changes. All code change is purely mechanical.

Change-Id: I17f4b71c0314e555d9f7dc1a935865865dd06c51
